subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: Well, I was thinking that there would be less craziness with two fonts, due to the issue I mentioned: if someone has a document that uses the Thoth font and
messageBody:
Well, I was thinking that there would be less craziness with two
fonts, due to the issue I mentioned: if someone has a document that
uses the Thoth font and then installs a new version that is also
called Thoth with a different key mapping, the document will become
scrambled. Also, if there are two versions, people can try out the new
version before telling us how much they love or hate it.

I guess the fact that no one has commented means that it's not a big
deal to anyone. If that's the case, then I'd say (of course) let's go
ahead and give it a try.

Ted

PS. By the way, have you checked out the fonts in the shawalphabet
group? There are some interesting ideas: serifs, monospace, a typeface
of uniform capital height (oh, the sacrilege!), and one that looks
like it was made from a photocopy of the original shavian printing of
"Androcles and the Lion."


On Nov 30, 2007 9:54 PM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > I actually suggested releasing a new version of Thoth that uses the
> > QS-SAMPA mapping. Let's call it Thoth No. 2 for the moment. This would
> > allow people to install and use the new version side-by-side with the
> > old one, leaving any documents that were created with the original
> > Thoth unaffected. It would make sense for new development to continue
> > with Thoth No. 2, while Thoth would remain in its present state.
> >
> > Ted
> >
> > PS. Small correction: you meant 'H' instead of 'F' below for the
> > present assignment for Thither.
> >
>
> Thanks for the correction.
>
> I didn't want to create another font unless we had agreement. Otherwise,
> we will have all sorts of craziness and texts will become more confusing
> than they are now.
>
> It doesn't seem like anyone has answered your thread, at any rate. How
> are we supposed to know how to go?
>
> Paul
>
>
